awd_titl_txt: INFEWS/T2: Cyber-Based Decision Support Strategies to Achieve  Consensus for FEW System Sustainability using Incentive and Policy  Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
The Midwest is quite different from other parts of the country in that little to no irrigation is required for farming. In fact, soils and topography in the Midwest, and particularly Iowa, trend toward waterlogged conditions. Farmers fertilize fields to maximize crop yield for both food and biofuel production, but a mismatch in timing between periods of high drainage water flux and nitrogen movement in early spring and crop uptake in the summer, results in excess nitrogen being transported through waterways to the Gulf of Mexico, causing detrimental environmental, societal and economic impacts. Driving much of the decision-making at local levels are policies and incentives implemented at higher levels, and vice versa, with no real understanding of the potential unintended consequences. This project aims to enable understanding of the impact of such policies and incentives on separate stakeholders associated with Food, Energy, and Water (FEW) sectors, as well as overarching system stakeholders, such as the federal government. More importantly, the research has the potential to impact the ways in which decisions are made in and about FEW system so as to ensure resilience and sustainability.
 
The project focuses on research questions pertaining to understanding the FEW inter-dependencies, modeling the value statements of each FEW stakeholder, developing new multi-attribute utility models to enable consensus building among FEW stakeholders, enabling coordinated decision making through incentives and policies designed to achieve the desired behaviors at the FEW system level, and developing visualization and simulation-based decision support tools to support consensus building of stakeholders using the methods developed.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Innovations at the Nexus of Food-Energy-

por.por_cntn:
In Iowa and other states especially in the Midwestern United States, agriculture is rainfed. While agriculture and other uses usually thus don't compete for water resources, there are nonetheless complicated interrelationships between food, energy, and water. This project studies the Iowa food-energy-water nexus specifically, developing a framework and the associated data to understand the nature of thes complicated interrelationships through gathering, harmonizing, and summarizing publicly available data regarding weather, agricultural and livestock production, nitrogen fertilization, food production, biobased energy production, streamflow, and water quality. We created interactive visualilzation tools that allow the user (other researchers, watershed managers, policymakers, or members of the general public) to explore how the elements of the Iowa food-energy-water system relate to one another.

Using these data, we developed frameworks that mathematically linked the agricultural production systems with water quality implications and biobased energy capacity. These frameworks allows for the evaluation of tradeoffs across these systems, with the goal of being able to discern "sweet spots" where multiple goals could be achieved together: robust agricultural production that generates both food and energy, and water quality that meets the needs of the community.

This work also established methods that can be adapted to other complex and interconnected systems where changes in one part of the system cause ripple effects into other parts of the system, and where improvements in one area can cause challenges in another.

 


Last Modified: 02/17/2025
Modified by: Amy L Kaleita
